dialogues.speaker: NEWS FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: MTV's Kurt Loder reports from the Berlin Wall. We see fro the MTV news footage that massive crowds are assembling. EAST GERMAN SOLDIERS stand on the Wall, holding an MTV umbrella, an iconic symbol of the times.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: We MOVE ON a reflection of Perceval on the television. Perceval leans in, shuts off the television and stands wi clear objective. Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is electric as West Germans carry hammers, chisel and pickaxes with purpose towards the Berlin wall. We see Perceval turn the corner into a dark alleyway near parked Saab 900 Turbo. Perceval sees a figure in the shad and slows.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose that’s it. We’ll be obsolete by morning. I’1l be back in London, and you... back to the party. We hear the faint sounds of HAMMERS STRIKING against concrete.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The simplicity of our struggle crumbles as that wall comes down. The lines on the map drawn by men who never faced the risk themselves will be harder to see. In the distance, the CROWDS’ CHEERS are heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different world is approaching. More volatile. More corrupt. There will be no ideologies to protect us. Just the brutal and cold conscience of commerce. Perceval’s eyes follow a group of West Germans with hand tools moving towards the Wall.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Extortion... Whoever has the list in this new world has all power. Without it? Just a target. Perceval turns back to the wordless figure in the shadows

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We played our hands. Hell, I’m just glad to see your face at this moment, as the ramparts of tyranny fall into the history books. Perceval smiles softly to himself as he looks towards the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen to them. In the faint light, we see the flash of gunmetal. We hear a GUNSHOT BARK out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “LONDON, NOVEMBER 11, 1989 - TWO DAYS LATER” A bathtub filled with ice cubes and freezing water. A wom appears from beneath the surface. This is LORRAINE BROUGHTON. Broughton’s body is athletic and strong but also patchwor bruises and cuts from the last ten days. She pulls a towe across her body, steps from the cold water and pours two fingers of Stoli into glass. Broughton looks down at the words “Hotel Moskva” on the label and then to the mirror. She CLICKS on the dial of shitty RADIO. We hear David Bow “Cat People Putting out Fire.” Broughton opens a vanity drawer. Next to the cosmetics i framed photo of her and a handsome man in front of the Bl Mosque in Istanbul. Broughton stares down at the photo fo moment, held by a memory and then reaches for a compact. Broughton covers her contusions with makeup and dresses i Navy crepe wool skirt suit from Chanel, heels and Jackie- sunglasses. Simple and sexy. As she opens a Kelly bag we see a Browning Hi-Power at re next to a pack of Woodbine cigarettes. Broughton doesn’t to chamber check the weapon. It’s always loaded, cocked, locked and awaiting her command. She pulls a cigarette from the pack, steps out of the bathroom, glances at the her empty bed and lights her Woodbine. Broughton walks out her apartment door. Bowie’s voice builds as we follow her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning is crisp. A double-decker bus drives past wit “Boycott Apartheid” painted on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just across the Westminster Bridge sits a limestone and g post-modern fortress. This is the British headquarters of MI6. Broughton walks through the busy streets and into th Century House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through the lobby and towards a line of people waiting at the metal detectors. The SECURITY PERSO wave her straight through. She belongs here; she’s a bad Security walks her to a single elevator, inserts a key, a Broughton enters the elevator alone. The doors close.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: There is only one button, and that is an arrow down. Broughton pushes the button and rides the elevator for so time.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: As the doors open, she is meet by another two armed secur personnel who nod and wave her past them. Broughton walks down a long, top lit, Kubrickian 60s hal We see a remote video camera track her. No one else is do here, and the two security personnel are 100 yards away b now. Broughton stops at an unmarked door. We see another video camera lens focus on her, and the electronic DEAD BOLT CL the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The “BIN” is a sterile ISO-FAC (Isolation Facility) for t debriefing of operatives returning to England. The room i sparse. All the walls are covered in 60s acoustic sound t save for a two-way mirror on one wall. MR. ERIC GRAY, mid-sixties and capable, sits with EMMETT KURZFELD of the CIA at wooden table. Broughton enters and slows as she sees Kurzfeld.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: How was your flight?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable. Broughton takes a seat across from the two men. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Sir, what is he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: We thought it would be helpful to get Kurzfeld’s perspective. Gray leans back and sits next to Kurzfeld.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF THE TWO-WAY MIRROR
dialogues.text: We see a older man, “C,” watching. His face is reflected the glass of the two-way mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Given the scale of recent world events, C will not be joining us. Broughton looks straight into the two-way mirror and nods with the confidence that C is there.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ISO-FAC
dialogues.text: Broughton looks at Gray and Kurzfeld.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Let’s begin, for the record. Gray reaches across to a Nagra III reel-to-reel recording unit that rests on the desk. Gray CLICKS the recording DI

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Under formal direction of the Joint Intelligence Committee: The following will serve as first contact and operational archive for Her Majesty’s Military Intelligence Section 6. Recorded on the 11th of November 1989. The voices of record are as follows, Senior Directorate Officer Eric Gray, Senior Case Officer Emmett Kurzfeld of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, and returning British Operational Officer Lorraine Broughton. Gray leans forward and begins the interview. GRAY (CONT’D) Tell us about Berlin. Were you there when Perceval was shot? Broughton calmly replies to Gray.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: No. Broughton looks to the two-way mirror and then to Kurzfel Gray scribbles down a note in a folder stamped “Top Secre in front of him and looks up at Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Let’s start from the beginning, shall we? A GRAFFITI TITLE CARD SCRAWLS OUT: “THE COLDEST CITY”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “LONDON, NOVEMBER 2, 1989 - NINE DAYS AGO” Hard rain. Broughton walks up the wide stairs of Century House. A handmade Fox umbrella shelters her from the weat  INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS The office is classic British Empire. Framed conquest map hang on the walls. A Regent desk in dark wood and oxblood leather chairs. Gray and another man, the Chief of the Se Intelligence Service known only as "“C,” sit across from another.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Broughton speaks four languages, and her Russian is excellent. Cc What about her field craft and perishable skills?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: She's an expert in Escape and Evasion, NATO and Warsaw Pact Weapons systems, and hand-to-hand combat. Cc Knowing the reds as I do, she'll need to use every damn one of them. There is a KNOCK on the office DOOR. Neither Gray or C st as Broughton enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Sorry to pull you in on short notice, Lorraine. You know C, of course. Broughton looks to the emotionless man who remains seated a straight-back chair.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. C motions towards a chair, and Broughton sits at the tabl and opens a pack of Woodbine cigarettes. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Mind if I smoke, sir? Gray pulls a cadet lighter from his pocket, leans across desk and lights Broughton’s Woodbine. Broughton takes a d off of her cigarette and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I‘ll get straight to the point. How well do you know, James Gascione?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to say hello... We did work together several years back in Istanbul. Gray and C share a quick look, trying to decipher if she lying to them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: As of yesterday morning Gascione was reported as incommunicado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “WEST BERLIN, NOVEMBER 1, 1989” 5 AM. Snow is falling. Most Berliners in the French, Brit and American sectors of this divided city are asleep. A dependable-looking middle-aged man runs down the empty street.(The same man from the photo in Broughton’s vanity This is JAMES GASCIONE.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who was Gascione handling? Gascione’s shoes pound the pavement. His lungs burn. Each quick exhale leaves a ghostly trail behind him. Remember gradation of fear in Gascione’s eyes as he glances over h shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gascione was running an agent codenamed Spyglass, a Stasi officer. Two ROUGH MEN chase after him through the snow. They are business. They are KGB. Gascione cuts through a backyard, hurdles several fences, vaults over a brick wall and lands. He checks over his shoulder again. Nothing. Maybe he lost them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Spyglass had just delivered a list to Gascione. Gascione sprints towards the river and glances again just as... ... the ROAR of an ENGINE gets his attention. Gascione h his hands out on instinct, headlights blinding him until feels the front of a sedan SLAM into his legs just above knees. Gascione’s body is lifted and then violently pinned again parked car. Pain surges through his body as he looks down his mangled legs. The sedan reverses a few feet, and Gasc crumples facedown onto the snowy pavement. The two rough men slowly jog up to the scene as an averag looking man, YURI BAKHTIN emerges from the car and moves towards Gascione.

dialogues.speaker: BAKHTIN
dialogues.text: Look at me. Gascione’s eyes tilt upward at Bakhtin.

dialogues.speaker: GASCIONE
dialogues.text: You... cossack... bastard! Bakhtin presses the barrel of a Makarov pistol onto Gascione’s forehead. The MAKAROV BARKS OUT, and Gasicone consumed by the white halo of a muzzle flash. Silence. Bakhtin grabs Gascione’s wrist and removes a classic “” C Bucherer ” wrist watch. Bakhtin nods towards the two roug men, who lift Gasicone’s lifeless body from the blood-soa snow and dump it into the river Spree.

dialogues.speaker: C, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Gascione is dead. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Broughton lowers her cigarette without a word.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: The Jerries fished him out of the Spree River this morning. A West German coroner extracted a 9x18mm from the base of his skull.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Soviets. Gray sets down a black-and-white photo of an average-look MAN in a Soviet military uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our sources point to Yuri Bakhtin, a lead KGB officer who was ticketed out of Berlin on Aeroflot to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You want me in Moscow? Cc Bakhtin never arrived in Moscow. Gray picks up the photo and scans the documents within a (Top Secret) folder stamped “UK eyes only.”

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: So either our man on the ground is wrong, or Bakhtin pulled a switch and is now lost to us. Broughton takes another drag from her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Gascione was en route to where?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Our Head of Berlin operations when he was assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: How sensitive is the list?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Spyglass claimed it was a complete inventory of the identities and locations of every active clandestine officer. Broughton lowers her cigarette as a thin ribbon of smoke curls up towards the low ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Is that even possible? Cc The real question must be: is it wise to hope it’s not possible instead of proving it is? There is a moment of silence in the room. A challenge has just been laid down.  10.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Everyone is hunting for it: the Yanks, the Frogs, us, and the Soviets for sure. Cc Tell her the rest of the good news.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Spyglass disclosed the list would expose a double agent by the name of “Satchel” within the allied intelligence network. Cc You find Satchel in this embarrassing mess and we'll hang him for treason. Broughton exhales smoke from her lungs and hardens to the truth of this knowledge. Cc (CONT'D) The list is the whole damn chessboard. Whoever controls it controls the Cold War.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Berlin is already on a short fuse. Hungary has dismantled hundreds of kilometers of the Iron Curtain since May. Last month, East Germans stormed the FRG’s embassies in Prague and Warsaw. They were given immunity and sent to West Germany. Cc Gorbachev’s glasnost nonsense has his people hopeful, and there is nothing worse than a hopeful enemy.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: The Wall won’t last much longer. David thinks it might even fall before Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: David, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: David Perceval is our number one in Berlin. We are sending you to link up with him.  11.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’ve never been to Berlin, and if Bakhtin has the list, he’s on the run. Gray sits behind the Regent desk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: We don’t think he does. There’s no question he would have taken it straight to Moscow. Cc The list is still in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Perceval is searching for it, but we want another pair of hands at the tiller as it were. C leans ever so slightly forward in his chair to commit importance to his words.

dialogues.speaker: C, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Most of the allied officers have been in Berlin for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “EAST BERLIN, NOVEMBER 2, 1989” Perceval slams a empty shot glass of whiskey down on the We hear Public Enemy’s Chuck D coming through the SPEAKER with “Fight the Power.” Drunk East German youth fill the place. It’s a strange mix of punk, hip hop, and anti-East German establishment. Perceval takes some D-marks from a KID for a bottle of Ja Daniels and a old Penthouse magazine. Another East German hands him money, and Perceval hands over a pair of Levi's Perceval has a nice little side business in selling contraband. Cc (V.0.) With no embassy to watch over them, they play by their only rules. Perceval sees a clean-cut East German enter and sit at a quiet table near the bar.  12. This is SPYGLASS. He is the real reason Perceval is in the East. Perceval m across the room and joins him at the table. Perceval hand small brown bag of contraband (canned food, Jack Daniels women’s jeans) to Spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The Jordache jeans were not easy.

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: They are for my wife’s birthday.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Let me cut right to the bone. Where is the goddamn list?

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: No joke.

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: I gave it to Gascione last night.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Gascione never showed. Spyglass looks up at Perceval with consternation settling his brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do you think I jumped the Wall, and I made contact with you?

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I followed all the orders. Look, I was careful. I met Gascione in Friedrichshain. He took the list from me. Spyglass’'s eyes are filling with despair.

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I did my part. I have risked everything.... You must to get me and my family across!

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Calm down. Perceval studies Spyglass for a moment.  13.

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: Are you going to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I’ve thought about it... However, I can’t ignore the fact you are telling me the truth. Spyglass takes a breath as he controls his anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you make a copy of the list?

dialogues.speaker: SPYGLASS
dialogues.text: No... I memorized it.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The entire list? Spyglass nods. Suddenly, the front door of the club is ki in. We see the green-gray uniforms of the EAST GERMAN STA OFFICERS surge into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddamn it. Perceval scans the room. An EAST GERMAN BARTENDER quickly motions to him.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Move! Perceval and Spyglass avoid the chaos of the room. The bartender pulls back a small service door to reveal a hallway. The bartender, Perceval, Spyglass, and several patrons ru down the hallway to the door leading outside. Perceval op the door to see two STASI OFFICERS standing directly in f of him.

dialogues.speaker: STASI
dialogues.text: (in German) You? Your papers! Now! Spyglass and the others are in the hallway, unseen to the Stasi. Perceval reaches into his pocket and pulls out a w leather wallet. He steps towards the Stasi and in the sam motion, throws the wallet into one officer’s face as a distraction. Perceval punches one Stasi in the throat and knees the other in the family jewels. Both drop to the al and writhe in pain.  14. Perceval looks back through the door, still open a few in as Spyglass and the others are witness to his burst of violence.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I'll be in contact. Perceval steps past the two Stasi on the ground and slowl jogs away down the alley and into the night.

dialogues.speaker: C, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: It seems Berlin has its way with the younger generation. It’s infectious, an epidemic really. They’re all feral and have gone native. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Broughton exhales her Woodbine and stares at Gray and C through the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: You have no family, no colleagues, no friends there. Cc No history to confuse your loyalties. You don’t even know Perceval. C stands and slowly walks towards the threshold of the of door. C pauses with his back to the room. Cc (CONT'D) When that bloody Wall comes crashing down, we don’t want to be under it. I want that list, Broughton. Bring it back home, and you'll find yourself at Buckingham for tea. C moves out the door, and Broughton looks back across the desk at Gray.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: I recommended you for this. So, do try and look grateful. Gray hands Broughton the TS folder.  15. GRAY (CONT’D) I know, it’s short notice. H/WAR suggested you use Gladys Lloyd, as she was never compromised. Commit everything to memory and then burn it all. Gray points to a large metal “burn can” for documents in corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A car will take you to your flat. Pack and then go straight to Heathrow. Remember, Lorraine, trust no one. Gray walks toward the office door. Broughton flips open t folder to a black-and-white photo of BER-1, David Perceva

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What’s he like, sir? David Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval carries a flashlight and takes a pull off a fift JD. He walks briskly and makes his way through a covert tunnel network towards West Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: David Perceval is a royal pain in the ass. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Gray stops and turns at his office door.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: However, he is arguably one of the best damn spies to ever serve the Crown. My office is yours. Gray steps out of the office, and Broughton opens the TS folder in front of her. PRE-LAP on soundtrack: “One Thing Leads to Another” by Th Fixx.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton is in a window seat. We see a couple empty mini bottles of Stoli on the tray in front of her and hardcove copy of Trevanian’s “Shibumi”. Broughton looks out the wi at the bleak November sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton walks off the Pan Am flight and towards the passport control kiosks. She hands the West German PASSPO OFFICER her UK passport. He looks at the passport photo a then to Broughton. He flips through the pages with scruti gives her another look and then stamps her passport and w her through. We follow Broughton into the uncluttered airport terminal loose crowd waits for the arriving international traveler From this crowd, a GENTLEMAN steps forward, all business, extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Ms. Lloyd? Broughton slows to a stop. The Gentleman’s British accent good, perhaps too good. GENTLEMAN (CONT’D) Mr. Perceval was running late. He sent me to pick you up. Broughton scans the terminal then looks back to the Gentleman. GENTLEMAN (CONT’D) Checked bags?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Please, follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton eyes her surroundings as they cross into a park lot. We see an attractive WOMAN turn from a phone booth, watch them, then methodically dial a number on the pay phone.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forest green BMW 2002 sedan is isolated at the end of t parking lot. The Gentleman and Broughton climb in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gentleman pulls out of the airport parking lot and on the main route. They drive in silence. Broughton looks into her side mirror and notices a Saab 9 Turbo tailing them.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Well... it’s a remarkable time to be in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: That so? Broughton looks again to her mirror and sees the Saab is still there.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: The music, nightlife and great restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You've got a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: For the beautiful people, go to the Palm for a drink. Broughton looks back to the mirror. The Saab speeds up be them and taps the BMW 2002 in a perfect PIT maneuver. Broughton quickly buckles her seat belt. The Gentleman is busy controlling the car to notice Broughton reach across depress the button to his seat belt. The BMW spins off th road, and Broughton braces for impact. The BMW slams into a metal guard rail. The WINDSHIELD SHATTERS, and the Gentleman is ejected onto the hood. Broughton relaxes and looks out at the bloody and moaning body of her driver. A figure drags the Gentleman off the and onto the frozen ground. We see Perceval look back thr the shattered glass at Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Welcome to Berlin.  18. Perceval stuffs a rag in the Gentlemen’s mouth and secure his mouth, ankles and hands with duct tape. Broughton unbuckles her seat belt and steps out of the BMW.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I could have handled him.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I have no doubt. Question is: What were you waiting for? Perceval drags the Gentleman across to his idling Saab. T boot is already open.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Who does he work for?

dialogues.speaker: KGB.
dialogues.text: Perceval dumps the Gentlemen into the boot. The Gentleman starts to realize what is happening. Broughton unloads a right hand into his face, more as a fuck you to Perceval anything. The Gentleman’s body goes limp. Perceval shoots a look, impressive.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am on the ground five minutes and get blown.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You’re not blown. Perceval slams the boot closed.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: He knew my name.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Troubling.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: And yours.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Not surprised. Broughton and Perceval move and get into the car.  19. INT./EXT. PERCEVAL’S SAAB - CONTINUOUS The inside of the car is littered with Wienerwald wrapper and empty beer cans. Perceval jams the Saab into gear and speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: How would anyone know I was on that flight? Perceval turns with a peripheral smile.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Those are the kinds of questions that keep us up late at night.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: We should message the home office and let them know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Christ and Mother Mary. London sent you to sort this mess out?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I just go where I am told.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Story of our lives. Checkpoint Charlie, by the way. Perceval points out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’m not here to collect postcards.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Ahhh... You’re all business under that lipstick. Broughton ignores the remark.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I was told you'd be briefed.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Your cover is civil service? Gladys Lloyd, Cambridge-educated lawyer sent by James Gascione’s family to return the body and effects of their now-deceased son, a British subject.  20. Perceval looks for a reaction but gets nothing from Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just how in the hell the suits think that’s going to help find our damn list is beyond me. Picking up Gascione’s body won’t take much time.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I‘1l just have to be creative. Perceval points outside the car again.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Brandenburg Gate. My office is just there... I suppose HQ thinks there’s no point in replacing Gascione with the Wall coming down.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Seems improbable after twenty-eight years.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Everything is probable. And that assertion confirms to me you don’t know the first damn thing about this city, so don’t pretend you do. The tension builds within the car. Perceval SLAMS on the brakes and slides the car to stop. Perceval gets out of t car, opens the trunk, pulls the KGB driver out and drags onto the sidewalk. We see a sign the reads: “Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic.” Perceval leans the KGB driver against the Soviet Embassy' wrought-iron gates. Within the compound several SOVIET GU start to move towards the gates.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Sending my old friend Bremovych a message. Perceval stomps his foot across the driver’s face for goo measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. EAST BERLIN’S HOHENSCHONHAUSEN PRISON- NIGHT We see a man built like a Soviet T-10 battle tank. He wea gray Soviet translation of a Brooks Brothers suit and is business as he moves into the room. This is ALEKSANDER BREMOVYCH, KGB. A dozen STASI OFFICERS have six EAST GERMAN PUNK ROCKERS B-BOYZ from the underground night club lined up in their underwear against the wall. There is a wooden table in th center of the room and nothing more. Bremovych sets a car of Russian “Belomorkanal” cigarettes on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in German) You’re not free to go. You may never be free to go. Unless you tell me what I want to hear? Bremovych lights a filter-less Belomorkanal from a pack o twenty five. Four Stasi officers drag a young man over an SLAM him face down onto the table. Bremoyvch holds a smal B/W photo of Bakhtin. BREMOVYCH (CONT’D) (in German) Have you seen this man?

dialogues.speaker: EAST GERMAN
dialogues.text: (in German) No. Bremoyvch nods and lays down another photo of Spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in German) Last night at the club, did you see this man?

dialogues.speaker: EAST GERMAN
dialogues.text: (in German) No. Bremoyvch takes a long drag on the filter-less cigarette then jams it into the young East German’s eye. The young howls in pain and buckles under his captor’s hands. Bremo lights another cigarette and holds up the carton for the of young men to witness.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in German) If I must, I will use all of them to get the truth from you.  22. Bremovych turns back to the whimpering young East German.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. PERCEVAL’S SAAB —- CONTINUOUS Perceval and Broughton are driving through the streets of West Berlin. We see outside, a massive wall of graffiti-covered concre that divides East and West. Broughton

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I didn’t travel as a QM, so I need you to supply me with a firearm.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: This is Berlin, not Tombstone.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Gascione was assassinated, and I was just set up by the KGB.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: If the KGB wants you dead, you’1l need more than good looks and a pistol. looks out the side window.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Turn left here and take me to my hotel.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: They said you’d never been to Berlin. How in the hell do you know where your hotel is?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I can read a map, you chauvinistic sonofabitch. Perceval SLAMS on the brakes and pulls the car to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You may not be declared here by Her Majesty, but I am still the head of this goddamn station, and you'll respect me.  Broughton Broughton her small

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Patrick 23.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Respect is a two-way street, Mr. Perceval. Clearly, you don’t want me here. However, C himself gave me this job.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: c is an arrogant lapdog and doesn’t know fuck all about the world past the edge of his desk! opens the door and steps out.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Perceval. crosses the hardscrabble street and walks towards hotel, never looking back.

dialogues.speaker: BERLIN
dialogues.text: Nagel print hangs on the wall. The room is equal parts Euro-chic and Miami Vice. We hear the RUNNING WATER from the bathroom. Broughton sits on the edge of the bed watching MTV news on a color Zenith.

dialogues.speaker: KURT LODER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The civil disobedience in East Berlin continues to build momentum. The disenfranchised youth leaders shout out their protests through the tear gas and water cannons. One eyewitness tells of police beating the peaceful demonstrators with batons. Broughton turns off the sound on the Zenith. She moves th hardcover of “Shibumi” onto the nightstand, picks up the rotary telephone, dials, and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Guten Abend. Ich bin Fraulen Lloyd, auf der Britische Botschaft Khan, Uh... Kann ich mit der Coroner Sprechen?

dialogues.speaker: MORGUE EMPLOYEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You are English? Why do you require the coroner?  24.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’ve been sent to arrange the return of a British subject, recently dead... I’m told you have the body.

dialogues.speaker: MORGUE EMPLOYEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nobody works tomorrow. It’s Sunday. Call Monday, in the morning. Auf Wiedersehen. Broughton hears a CLICK and sets the phone on its cradle. Broughton walks into the bathroom and turns off the cold water filling the chipped porcelain tub. She turns to a h dozen little ice buckets filled to the top and then dumps them into the bathtub. This is her daily ritual, the ice bath. Broughton switches off the bathroom light. The ZENITH is still PLAYING in the other room. She undresses in the fai light and steps into the freezing water without pause. Broughton sinks up to her nose with only her pale green e on the icy surface... then disappears below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “NOVEMBER 3, 1989” Broughton stands on the steps of a colorless apartment building and RINGS a call box BUZZER. Across the street, fifty feet away, is the graffiti-covered Berlin Wall snak through the neighborhood. INT. ATTACHE’S OFFICE - DAY Surveillance gear and monitors sit on a small table. Contraband is everywhere: LPs, Jack Daniels, cartons of L Strikes and Marlboro Reds. We hear the BUZZER, and Percev still in his clothes from last night, stirs and answers t call box.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Perceval? It’s Ms. Lloyd. You left a message at my hotel.  25.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I'll be right down. Perceval grabs his coat and moves towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton waits and watches a couple of children kick a soccer ball against the Wall. We see the same WOMAN from airport watching from a parked beige Mercedes 300D. After a few moments, Perceval exits his building.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Let’s take a walk. They start down the street, side by side.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: About yesterday... in the car... the chauvinistic remarks. I shouldn’t have -- Broughton, without slowing her stride, interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Apology accepted. Perceval looks at Broughton and then clears the air betwe them with a simple nod.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: It’s as cold as a witch’s tit on the dark side of the moon today.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I like the cold.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: No wonder they kept sending you to Moscow. Broughton looks at Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t act surprised. We both read each other’s file. Perceval stops at a street vendor selling currywurst from rolling cart. Perceval turns to Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buy you breakfast?  26. Broughton doesn’t need to say no for Perceval to understa He buys two, and they walk through a broadstone archway. We see a sign that reads “TIERGARTEN PARK.” They continue on the crushed gravel path until stopping n to a frozen duck pond. Perceval throws small pieces of hi currywurst bun out onto the ice.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t feed them bread. It's bad for their digestion. A thin man wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a heavy winter topcoat approaches. It’s Emmett Kurzfeld.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: She is right.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You damned Americans will back up anything in a skirt.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: You must be Ms. Lloyd. I am Kurzfeld. Broughton extends her hand.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. Kurzfeld’s hand stays in the warmth of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Kurzfeld here went to Princeton. Broughton slowly retracts her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kurzfeld thinks he knows everything... So you two should get along just fine.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: I’ve been in Berlin almost as long as David... Nobody wants the list to fall into Soviet hands. Broughton looks to Perceval.  27.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What else have you shared with him?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Just women and scotch.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: We watch out for one another. Broughton looks back to Kurzfeld.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I think Bakhtin is going to dump the list on the black market.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: If one of the Allies has it, we'd already know. If Moscow had it, there’s nothing we can do. So either Bakhtin puts it up for sale, or we'll never see it again.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: She’s smart.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You only say that because you had that same idea. Kurzfeld turns to Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: What’s the plan with Spyglass?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD
dialogues.text: I should be going. Let me know if the company can help in any way. Kurzfeld nods towards Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: KURZFELD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good day, Ms. Lloyd. Kurzfeld walks on alone through the park covered in rags snow and frozen grass.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Is there even a plan?  28.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Not yet, and if there was, I'd be damned if I'd share it with the Yanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NAGRA III keeps recording. The ashtray on the table i filled with several crushed Woodbines. Gray and Kurzfeld across at Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: So, how would you describe the situation on the ground those first couple of days?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Hostile.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: With Perceval?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: With everyone.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Who was in the country? Broughton pulls another Woodbine out of her pack.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You weren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is colorless. A lone figure walks through the col and across the “Bridge of Spies.” As the figure gets clos we see it is Bremovych. His KGB DRIVER is waits for him on the West German side.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Did she get the message?

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: (in Russian) I believe so.  29. Bremovych pauses for a moment and looks at the swollen fa and black eye of the driver.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Did the woman do that to you?

dialogues.speaker: GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: (in Russian) No. The Gentleman opens the side door of a black sedan.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: (in Russian) You’d look much worse if she touched you. Bremovych climbs in. INT. ATTACHE’S OFFICE - DAY Perceval and Broughton enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Can I take your coat? Broughton hands over her coat. She moves down a short hal as Perceval hangs her coat on a hook by the front door. Less chaos than the rest of Perceval’s apartment. A plain desk and two worn-leather club chairs. A bookshelf runnin the length of the room. A small TELEVISION PLAYS MTV Euro in the background.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: So this is what you get after years of service.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: In a complicated world, I prefer things to be simple. Broughton scans the shelves filled with volumes in six foreign languages, save for the “Great Books” that are al English.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You like to read.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Depends on the book... If I said Epictetus, I would be lying... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Volume 23... Chapter 15... “He who neglects what is done for what ought to be done, sooner effects his ruin than his preservation.” Broughton’s eyes settle onto Volume 23.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Machiavelli.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The prince of princes. Broughton turns back to Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: “It’s a double pleasure to deceive the deceiver.” A hint of a smile from Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Ahhh. Niccolé sounds sweeter somehow, coming from you. Perceval is at his desk and reaches for an eighteen-year- bottle of single malt from the Isle of Skye.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drink?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: No. We hear the German version of “Major Tom” by Véllig Losge PLAYING on the TELEVISION. Broughton picks up a “Penthouse” magazine from a stack on table. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Your library includes Larry Flint.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The champion of free speech. Broughton sets the magazine back down as Perceval pours t fingers of Talisker into a heavy glass.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am sorry about Gascione. Perceval raises the glass in silent tribute.  31.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: James was a gentlemen, one hell of a spy and a true friend. I know you were close. James told me as much. Broughton remains steady and without emotion. Perceval sl sips the scotch.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’ll need his address.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I’ve been there. The West Germans have been there. God only knows who else.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You always get your way? The slightest smile appears at the corner of Broughton’s mouth, then disappears.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: We'll let that question keep you up tonight. Perceval nods and lifts his glass of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: It’s down the street from Fehrbelliner platz. Brandenburgisher Strasse 10. It’s a walk-up. Fifth floor.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Gascione’s passport?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The police have his passport. He was carrying it.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Don’t you have a copy?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: No... but don’t worry your pretty little head. The Circus called me yesterday with the number.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Can you write it out for me?  32.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Already have. Perceval glances at his desk and hands her a piece of pap with Gascione’s passport number.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Where would you recommend for dinner and a drink?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Is that an invitation? Broughton gives him a silent look, and that’s all Perceva needs to have his question answered. Perceval moves back the front door and hands Broughton her coat from the hook

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well then, you can’t go wrong with the Ritz off Potsdamer. The venison is marvelous. Broughton turns for the attaché office door.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Perceval.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You’re welcome, and feel free to drop in anytime, Ms. Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton pops open the back on the hardcover novel of “Shibumi” to reveal a lead lined compartment. Inside: a Narga SN mirco recording unit and thin surveill microphone. With care Broughton tapes the wire to her lean body and t conceals the Narga SN recorder. Broughton checks herself the mirror. Perfect. Behind her, the bathtub of ice cubes drains. Broughton steps into the room and glances at the Zenith. We see news of the German protests growing in size around both sides of the Berlin Wall. Broughton grabs her dark coat and is out the door.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along a quiet street, just around the corner from Zoo Station, is a tiny watch repair shop. Broughton enters wi purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through orderly store filled with hundred grandfather clocks. A couple of patrons mill about the aisles. In the back of the shop, a middle-aged man known as the WATCHMAKER stares through magnified jeweler’s glas at the guts of a “Newman” Daytona.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I'd like to purchase a watch. The Watchmaker never looks up from his delicate work. Wit thick German accent:

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: I don’t sell watches. I only fix them.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am looking for an East German watch.

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: The East German watches aren’t worth wearing.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am looking for a Ruhla.

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: A Ruhla is very different.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I will pay a premium.

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: I sense you’re serious. Come back tomorrow before closing.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Thank you. Broughton exits the shop without another word, and the Watchmaker never looks up from the precision of his work.  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A working-class neighborhood. Broughton approaches the apartment building and deftly breaches her way inside. INT. GASCIONE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - STAIRWELL - NIGHT Broughton climbs up a dimly-light stairwell to the fifth floor landing. She quickly shims the lock and steps into apartment 5A without a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through Gascione’s apartment and studies details of a dead man. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her as she moves to the bedroom, examining. A closet of perfectly-folded clothes and shoes in neat ro The bed’s made with military corners. A porthole into Gascione’s precise and orderly life. Broughton steps into the living room. She walks towards a Biedermeier Secretaire desk and picks up a framed photo. We see a young James Gascione and David Perceval in the English countryside, Holland & Holland shotguns cradled o their shoulders and freshly-killed rabbits in both of the strong hands. Broughton sets the photo down and takes in the room. Outside the window, Broughton notices the building across street bathed in blue flashing lights. She leans towards window for a better view. We see German polizei cars roll to a stop. A dozen OFFICE advance towards the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through the hallway as she hears the poli five floors below. Broughton pushes a sofa out of the living room and down t short hallway. She pushes the sofa out into the stairwell landing. We hear POLIZEI BOOTS four floors below.  35. Broughton moves back to the kitchen and finds what she ne a box of steel wool and bottle of high-proof rubbing alco Broughton moves back down the hallway. We hear POLIZEI BOOTS three floors below. Broughton piles the steel wool on the sofa, soaks the sof and steel wool in rubbing alcohol and stands back. Broughton draws a black ski mask from her jacket pocket a pulls it over her head. We hear POLIZEI BOOTS two floors below. Broughton lights a match against the wall and tosses it o the soaked steel wool and sofa.

dialogues.speaker: WHOOOOM
dialogues.text: Broughton pushes the burning sofa down the stairs at the advancing polizei and forces them to dive out of the way. polizei push past flames and climb the stairs. Still wear the ski mask, Broughton ducks back in the apartment and w in the darkness. The first officer charges in with his baton in hand. Broughton slams the door and bolts it shut. As the office turns, Broughton strikes him with blinding speed and then hanging arm throws him to the floor. The officers outside in the hallway are POUNDING on the D Broughton picks the baton and then cracks it down on the officer. He is out cold. We hear the CHAMBERING of a breaching ROUND into a shotgu and Broughton rolls out of the way as the LOCK on the fro door EXPLODES inwards. Broughton bolts through the living room as a second offic grabs her from behind. Broughton snaps her head back, crushing his nose, and then hip throws her attacker throu the glass doors of the balcony. EXT. GASCIONE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT Broughton steps over the broken glass and the officer. Sh quickly climbs out onto the thin features of the building It’s not gymnastic pretty but sixty feet off the street, Broughton is strong and without fear. Broughton, now on the rooftop, quickly scans the building around her as she sprints across the flat roof.  36. Three polizei officers pull themselves onto the rooftop, the chase is on. Broughton jumps down a staggered rooftop lands and sprints with the polizei closing in. EXT. VARIOUS ROOFTOPS — CONTINUOUS Without slowly down, Broughton jumps across onto the next rooftop and lands safely. The polizei follow her with les elegance. Broughton leaps across an open gap between the last two apartment buildings, lands on a ledge and then jumps into void below. The three polizei run to the edge of the rooftop, only to the human wearing a ski mask and dark winter jacket land the thick nylon roof of a farmer’s market tent. Broughton slides down the tent roof, lands on her feet, a never looks back. The three polizei can do nothing but wa as the figure disappears into the evening crowds. PRE-LAP on the soundtrack: “Der Kommissar” by After the F

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton steps from a taxi and walks towards the doors o the Palm Restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soundtrack shifts to a piano player behind a Bosendorfer singing a slow and sexy club version of “Der Kommissar.” Broughton walks up to an empty space at the Art Deco bar.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Stoli on ice. The BARTENDER nods. Broughton puts a cigarette to her lip and turns slowly to the room. A PATRON holds out a Riga metal lighter with its flame burning. Without a word, Broughton leans into the fire, lights her smoke, and only when she pulls away do... We see the Soviet KGB agent, Bremovych.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Haben sie, fraulein?  37.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I don’t speak German.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: You are British? Broughton nods her head slowly through the smoke, studyin his voice.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: And you sound Polish, with a slight affect of Slovak. Are you from the Carpathian mountains?

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Impressive, Miss... ?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: This can’t be your only talent.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Talents can be overrated.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Now dedication, Loyalty that is rare.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I agree. Broughton goes back to her Stoli.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: How do you like Berlin, Ms. Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Exciting, so far. Mr?

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Bremovych. Are you on holiday?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: On business.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Aren’t we all. A woman steps to the bar behind Broughton. This is DELPHI LASALLE. She’s a mixture of punk rock and Peter Beard mus This the same woman who was watching Broughton at the air and on the street.  38.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I leave you alone for only a moment and already you are attracting admirers. Lasalle turns to Bremovych.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Monsieur, three is not always a crowd, but tonight it is.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Ahhh... French women. Bremovych looks at Broughton. BREMOVYCH (CONT’D) What about the British? Maybe we can make some sort of arrangement?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: My apologies. Good evening. Broughton shares a look with Bremovych, and then he exits past the restaurant tables towards the coat check.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Whoever you are, you have quite the high level of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: No more than that communist pig. Lasalle watches Bremovych leave and then turns back to Broughton with a smile that could end the Cold War.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Delphine LaSalle, and I am at your service.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What makes you think I need your service, mademoiselle? Lasalle gestures to the Bartender for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: A woman drinking alone is always in need of something. Allow me to be presumptuous; are you here for work or pleasure?  39.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am a lawyer for the British government. And you?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I was raised in Paris in the 18th arrondissement. My parents were teachers, and I made my way to West Berlin after studying at the Sorbonne.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: A respectable story. And what brought you here?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: The danger of course. The Bartender sets down a tumbler in front of Lasalle.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And a broken heart.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’m sure he regrets losing you. LaSalle smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I am sure she does. LaSalle takes a drink and lets her sexuality hang in the for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must join me for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What are we doing now?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: This place is pretentious. My friend owns a club, and I know the city well. You’d be surprised what secrets one overhears late at night out on the town.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Secrets?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: What every woman loves.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: The French will never change.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: It’s our charm... I'll give you the address. Tomorrow night, around eleven. Lasalle writes out the address on a cocktail napkin. We see several paparazzi start a frenzy of STROBES by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What is that about?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: David Hasselhoff is in town. Lasalle slides the address in front of Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until then. Lasalle moves towards the crowd of photographers and out the street. We see Perceval watching from a corner table, safe distance from being noticed by Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “NOVEMBER 4, 1989” Broughton walks up the wide, brick steps of a government building. We see Lasalle across the street, watching Broughton ente the West Berlin City Morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CORONER walks Broughton through the spotless corridor

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: The body was identified by your attaché.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I believe so.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: This was not a question... It was a statement.  41.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I am sorry. This is the first time I've been sent to do this. I was told you'd have his passport.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: It will be released with the body. After you, Ms. Lloyd. The Coroner holds the door open for Broughton. INT. CITY MORGUE - EXAMINATION ROOM — CONTINUOUS A bright, sterile world. Along the wall, stainless steel racks of cold storage hold dead bodies. The Coroner heave cold rack open and pulls back a thin cotton sheet from th body. Broughton stares down at James Gascione in the stillness of death. There is a moment of contemplation fo fallen friend or maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: He was your colleague?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: A different department.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Which department? Broughton looks at the Coroner, nice try.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: A different one.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: You have the transfer papers? Broughton hands the transfer papers to him.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I filled them out while I was waiting downstairs. The Coroner studies the paperwork carefully.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Wait one moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Is something the matter?

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: The passport number is incorrect.  42.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: There must be some mistake. The FCO gave my attaché the number.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: It’s your responsibility to give me the correct papers.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: It’s obviously the right man. The corner pulls the sheet over the body and pushes the c rack back into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: I will not release this body.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: It’s a simple clerical error.

dialogues.speaker: CORONER
dialogues.text: Ms. Lloyd, in Germany we don’t make clerical errors. I would advise you to talk to your embassy in Bonn. I must inform my superiors. The Coroner moves back to the door and holds it open for Broughton without another word. INT. ATTACHE’S OFFICE - DAY Perceval sits behind his bare desk with his dark eyes loc onto Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You gave me the wrong number.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The hell I did. Perceval grabs the morgue’s transfer papers from Broughto

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wrote “16” where it should have been “76.” Perceval slams the paper down onto his desk.  43.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You realize the coroner will now inform the chief of police of West Berlin. They'll probably refuse to release the body for another week while they investigate. Not to mention they'll now suspect Gascione was an officer. Perceval pushes back from his desk and looks dead center Broughton’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perceval and Broughton tread through the crisp afternoon parallel to the colorful graffiti-covered concrete of the Berlin Wall.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The passport number. You’re being “creative.” Broughton’s face shows nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You said yourself it wouldn’t take much time to pick up the body.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I should send you back to England.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I don’t think C would appreciate that very much. Perceval turns to Broughton.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Look... if you’re going to be here for awhile, we had better play nice with one another. Two US ARMY jeeps with SOLDIERS from the 2nd Battalion 6t Infantry patrol past. Perceval gestures towards the Brandenburg Gate.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How would you fancy a trip to the East tonight? I have to go check for word from Spyglass.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You meeting him?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I never have. James turned him. Spyglass hasn't surfaced since the exchange of the list.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What about Bakhtin? London said he mostly likely had it.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Trust your gut. If Bakhtin wanted the Russians to have it he would have given it to them. He knows the importance of that list. Bakhtin gone so deep we won't find him until he comes up to make his move. They climb the stairs of a wooden observation platform fo tourists and West Germans to see over the Wall to the Eas

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at it... Berlin is a city under siege, surrounded by seventy miles of barbed wire and concrete, three hundred and ten guard towers, sixty-five anti-vehicle trenches, and forty thousand heavily-armed Soviet-trained frontier troops.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: All that and five thousand of the GDR citizens still had the guts to escape. Perceval points and moves his hand along the ribbon of concrete. He stops at a tenebrific group of buildings on eastern side of the Wall.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: There’s a letter box around the back of Gantzstrasse. Terrified or not, if Spyglass knows anything, he is supposed to leave word at that dead drop.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Home office said Spyglass had exposed an Allied double codenamed Satchel.  45.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Nonsense. I’ve heard about Satchel for years.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You don’t think he is real?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Look if he exists, which I highly doubt, he has more at stake than anyone. When this wall comes down Satchel will be ducking bullets from both sides. Perceval looks at Broughton and sizes up the moment.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's drop the official pretense. Everything in this conversation can be off the record. Broughton nods.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: London sends you to gather a body and orders us both to find a list. Why?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Because the KGB killed Gascione and took the list from him.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: Partly true... Look, We are all on the damn list. You. Me. Every one of us, patriots and traitors alike.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: That’s a bold statement.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: You do this job long enough, you become fairly accurate.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Let’s not forget what we do for a living. We turn people against their closest friends, family members, and the very countries they profess to love. We exploit, corrupt, and bribe business and government officials for any scrap of advantage... Win at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two World Wars in this century alone makes that rather clear.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: To win once, you can play by the rules, but to win every time, you have to play dirty... You think London is worried for other reasons?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: I know they are. This list is about covering the Queen’s ass not the officers that serve the Crown.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Welcome to Berlin. Perceval smiles at his own words being repeated to him. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) You're not worried Spyglass could be setting us up?

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: It’s a possibility. Even if the Soviets knew, I doubt the KGB would try to turn Spyglass back or even pay for a train ticket to Siberia.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What would they pay for? Perceval calmly replies:

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: A bullet. The two stand in silence and look out over the Wall to th colorless East beyond. The stakes are clear to both of th life or death.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I can’t cross tonight. I’m meeting someone.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL
dialogues.text: The little mademoiselle from the bar last night? Broughton glances at Perceval.  47.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tell you to go to the Ritz for venison, and you go to the Palm for drinks. Perceval studies Broughton for a second.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you’re the only one doing their job? Broughton says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PERCEVAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just be careful. You can’t trust Frenchies. Perceval walks down the wooden stairs and leaves Broughto standing alone on the observation platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton removes thin wire from her body and sets it bac into the hardcover book. We see several fully recorded SN mirco tapes on the desk. Broughton stands on the bed, sli a ceiling tile back and places the novel, Narga SN and recorded tapes in the small space and slides the ceiling back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night sky is without warmth. Broughton walks along th rain-soaked Kurfiirstendamm. West Germans mill about the shopping district. Broughton moves into the crowds at Zoo Station and exits the other side. She crosses the quiet street, looks over shoulder once to confirm no one is following her and then enters the small watch repair shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton proceeds to the back towards the workshop. The Watchmaker is hunched over another Swiss watch, never loo up from his work.

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: Your watch is ready. It’s on the counter in that plain envelope. Broughton picks up the plain envelope.  48.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: WATCHMAKER
dialogues.text: If it works to your satisfaction, we can discuss payment. Broughton puts the plain envelope inside her coat pocket without looking inside.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Very well. Broughton looks at the Watchmaker for a moment and then leaves. PRE-LAP on soundtrack: “The Politics of Dancing” by Re-Fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smoke-heavy room is full of West Berlin’s new wave yo Lasalle stands at the back of the room near the crowded b as Broughton enters and approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t certain you would show.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: How could I resist your invitation? Broughton lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: You are finished with your work?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I may be here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Then we have to enjoy ourselves. Lasalle hands Broughton a glass of Stoli on ice.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You pay attention. LaSalle lifts her drink in salute.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I look for pleasure in the details.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I’m sure.  49.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: What is it you’d like from me? In one movement, Broughton lifts and empties her glass of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Another drink to start. LaSalle orders another round.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Are you enjoying the club?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Not really. It’s pretentious. LaSalle smiles at Broughton, leans closer and whispers in ear.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: May I take you somewhere quiet, where we can talk? Broughton looks at LaSalle and off that look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton pushes Lasalle against the hallway wall, kissin her softly, then harder and with more passion.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Ma cherie. (beat) This is how you like it?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Broughton pushes open the club’s bathroom door just as tw young punks exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton locks the bathroom door as her winter coat fall the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: You like to play rough?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Sometimes.  50. Broughton’s hand wraps around the small of Lasalle’s back pulls a concealed handgun from Lasalle’s lean waist. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) When I’m the one holding the gun.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You've been following me since I arrived at Tempelhof -- outside the city morgue and my colleague's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: You are mistaken. Broughton backhands Lasalle across the face, sending her the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Why the gun? Lasalle looks up with a thin stream of blood at the corne her perfect mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Berlin is a dangerous city.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Especially if you keep lying. Lasalle stares up the barrel of her own gun.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Miss Broughton. You're not so well disguised as MI6 may think. You’re here, of course, because of the death of Gascione. Broughton holds the weapon steady.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: What do you know about his death?

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Only that I am interested... If someone is killing Allied officers, shouldn’t we all care?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You're with DSGE?  51. Lasalle nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: Why do you think your colleague was sanctioned?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: He was carrying a document.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: That list is very sensitive. Broughton cocks the hammer back on the pistol and drops t safety off.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I never said list. I said document.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: My colleagues in Paris were right. They informed me the “document” is very valuable. This is why you were talking to the watchmaker. Your looking for Bakhtin?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: There is a good chance it will float onto the black market. If Bremovych is still looking for it, Bakhtin hasn’t handed it off and clearly has other plans. Lasalle leans over and picks up Broughton’s winter coat.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: If it’s still in Berlin, it will surface. You must be careful. You are vulnerable. Lasalle hands Broughton her coat.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: You're a better liar than my station chief.

dialogues.speaker: LASALLE
dialogues.text: To be a spy takes a steady hand.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle. Broughton de-cocks LaSalle’s pistol and thumbs the safety  52. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Let me show you what takes a steady hand. Broughton pulls Lasalle closer, and they fall... INT. LASALLE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT .»+. onto the sheets of a simple bed. Lasalle’s hand push back along the wall... her fingers climbing against its r surface, finding the light switch. Broughton looks straight into Lasalle’s eyes which read e parts temptation and fear. Broughton leans in, kisses her gently bites her lower lip. Lasalle’s hand pulls down against the light switch and th bedroom goes dark. EXT. LASALLE’S APARTMENT BUILDING/INT. PERCEVAL’S SAAB - Broughton sits on the edge of the bed and exhales her cigarette smoke out the open window. The cold air feels g Lasalle awakes... We see Broughton’s coat slung over the chair. RACK FOCUS... Outside the window. A beat-to-hell Saab 900 Turbo stands out among the street parked cars. Perceval lowers a high-powered Nikon F3 and telephoto lens. We see a “Seceret Service Style” ear bud his ear. The headlights of the Saab illuminate, and Perce pulls out into the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton leans forward and taps her Woodbine in the asht A dozen used cigarettes rest there now. Gray threads a fr reel to reel onto the NAGRA III and CLICKS record.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: So you made contact with the French operative.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes... You could say that.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Could she be Satchel?  53.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: No. Gray looks at Kurzfeld and then scribbles a note into the folder.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: What was your assessment?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I believed she had information that I could either use or exploit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An etiolated morning light comes through the window. Broughton has the open plain envelope on the small desk i front of her. Broughton takes apart the back of the Ruhla wristwatch wi small screwdriver. She releases the pressure from the mai spring and disassembles the watch movement using the pry points. Broughton lifts the wheel plate and turns it over with a small tweezer. We see engraved on the inside are a column of numbers. Broughton removes the escape and sweep wheels. She sets t on the desk with the rest of the internal parts. Broughton lays out a map of West and East Berlin. She loo at the column of engraved numbers. First number in the sequence is 06. Broughton finds the number 06 on the map, and it tallies with Checkpoint Char Broughton looks to the next number: 7E. Broughton takes t tiny sweep wheel from the watch and rolls it on its edge times in the direction of East, matching the 7E directive and lands on the next engraved number 01. Broughton repeats this action from position 01. 3N is the next number, and Broughton rolls the sweep wheel 3 times the direction of North. She lands on number 12 on the gri coords of her map. Broughton looks to the engraved numbers again. 2E is the number. Broughton rolls across the map 2 times in the direction of East. She stops, lifts the sweep wheel and m the rendezvous point on the map.  54. Broughton commits every detail of the map to her memory a begins to reassemble the watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER: “NOVEMBER 5, 1989” Broughton waits to cross into East Berlin. A formidable- looking EAST GERMAN GUARD stares down at Broughton’s passport, then back into her face.

dialogues.speaker: EAST GERMAN GUARD
dialogues.text: You should have applied for a visitor’s permit. What kind of work do you do?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Legal affairs, I’m a lawyer. The East German Guard looks down again at her passport.

dialogues.speaker: EAST GERMAN GUARD
dialogues.text: Wait here. The East German Guard takes her papers and speaks with hi SUPERIOR as Broughton waits. The East German Guard makes phone call, then returns with Broughton’s passport and ha it back to her. EAST GERMAN GUARD (CONT’D) If you do not return before six o'clock, you will be arrested. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves past an assembly of protesting EAST GERMA YOUTH near the blank concrete Wall. Broughton walks the local streets. As she moves, she glan at her reflection in a store window. We see two young STASI OFFICERS shadowing her. Broughton steps up her pace. The two Stasi officers conti to follow her. Broughton moves through a crowded S-Bahn station and out other side. The Stasi still follow... farther back now.  55. Broughton moves towards a large set of shops at the base the East Berlin TV tower. We see a government sedan pull to the curb. The Stasi officers turn to the government sedan. Bremovyc and his driver are in the front seat. In the rear seat si two KGB officers, the same two rough men from Gascione’s assassination.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Bring her to me. The KGB officers step from the back of the car and join t two Stasi officers. Broughton now has double the trouble walking towards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves towards a local cinema named the Kino International.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through the doors and into the mid-centur modern lobby.

dialogues.speaker: THEATER
dialogues.text: Broughton quickly moves into the dark and packed theater. Stasi and KGB officers chase after her. We see Richard Attenborough’s “CRY FREEDOM” and a young Denzel Washington on the screen. Broughton egresses through the row of people, running dow the aisle, then behind the aged-silk movie screen. Broughton reaches up onto the movie theater wall and pull down hard on the FIRE ALARM! The audience jumps from their seats and floods the exits the Stasi and KGB pursue Broughton. Broughton melts into the crowd and disappears out the bac doors in the mass exodus of patrons.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bremovych and his driver pull to the curb at the rear of movie theater. The Stasi and KGB search the crowd outside Broughton. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BREMOVYCH
dialogues.text: Keep looking for her. The two KGB officers move away from Bremovych’s sedan and back towards the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broughton moves through the bombed-out neighborhood left from the Second World War. She enters an abandoned buildi on the southwest corner of Arnimplatz. INT. ABANDONED BUILDING - ROOFTOP —- CONTINUOUS Broughton moves up a set of crumbling stairs towards the roof. The Berlin Radio Tower looms close. Broughton steps onto the rooftop. We see the young Bartender from the East German Club sitt in one of two lawn chairs on the roof. His newly-dyed hai and tattoos are visible from under his plain jacket. This is MERKEL.

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL, (BARTENDER)
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL
dialogues.text: And you were followed.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I lost them twenty minutes ago near the Palast der Republik.

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL
dialogues.text: You're as good as your reputation.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: I'm already known by reputation?

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL
dialogues.text: To the right people.  57. Merkel sits in one of the lawn chairs and looks out acros the drab rooftops to the West.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: Is this the best place for a rendez- vous? Merkel points towards the Orwellian tower.

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL
dialogues.text: Keep your enemies close. Please have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MERKEL
dialogues.text: The watchmaker told me there has been great interest in the black market over the last few days.

dialogues.speaker: BROUGHTON
